fol.188r
[O]cto
b
[M
r
] Bodly.
May it please yo
r
good L. By yo
r
l
re
of
e 24 of Sept I
finde her
Ma
tie
discontented as if I had not bin so care-
full as imported her service, to calle for an answear from
e
States.
But my trust is in your L: for informing
her Hig
es
w
at
kinde of instance I have used, as all
my l
re
s will declare it, And yet I never thought it
meete to trouble yo
r
L: w
t
reporte of all my travels and
endevor
s
, at every tyme in
ticular
at I went about
my businesse. I hope her Hig
es
will be pleased to
give me credit in this case,
at I may reape some
other fruites then pensivenesse and grief, for my
painefull solicitation. And
where
as
againe
I am en-
joyned to proceede without admitting any dilatorie
answear; I protest unto your L. I knowe not in
e
world howe to doe it more effectually, then I have put
in tryall, having done in
at behalf both in publicke
and in privat, as muche as is possible, and more by
muche then is expressed in any point of my Instru-
ctions, aswell by special persuasions, as by other in-
sinuations of danger to
e Contrey: in so muche as
I have doubted in myne owne privat judgem
t
,
whether I kept in
at decor
u
, in regard of
e dignitie
and State of her Ma
tie
, to insist to earnestly, so often
so many sundrie wayes w
t
a people of this condition,
and so muche bounde unto her Hig
es
. And therfore
not prevailing w
t
so great importunitie I could wade
no further with them, but certefie by l
re
s, howe I founde
their dispositions. But sins
e receat of yo
r
L. l
re
s
the
Counsell of Estate
being come home to
e Hage,
upon
e writing of
e states, I laboured w
at
I could to
procure their advise to be presently given: but getting
notice under hand
at their drifte was altogether, to
send unto her Ma
tie
(as I have alwayes thought
they would) to cutte of all occasions of further
delayes, I lette them flatly understand, and withall
I made it knowen to
e College of
e States,
at if so
be they had no meaning to satisfie her Hig
es
, but
would happelie determine to send some Deputies unto
her, to deliver their excuses, they should alter
at
intent and keepe their Deputies at home: for so I
had bin willed to signifie unto them. This was
taken much to hart, that her Ma
tie
would refuse
in a cause of
at moment, to give them
e hearing:
fol.188v
and both
e States and
e Councell have consult[ed]
often for divers dayes together, w
at
course to tak[e upon]
it. For to forbeare to send at all, they thought [it]
might be taken for a weake resolution, sith the[y could]
not by their l
re
s make so cleare a demonstration [of their]
want of readie meanes, to give her Ma
tie
conten[tment,]
and to prevent therew
t
all
e effectes of her dis[pleasure,]
as by
e
effectes
verbals of those that might be p[urposely]
sent about it: whome they hoped at her Hig
es
[, upon]
their sute in
at behalf would be willing to adm[it.]
And yet to send upon presumption when they had [bin by]
me forewarned to refrayne, and so perhaps whe[n they]
came, to be rejected of her Ma
tie
they thought i[t would]
be caried over all partes of Christendome, and [more]
e multitude heere, who might thinke they w[ere]
forsaken, to accept of such conditions as
e Pea[cema-]
kers offer.
Muche a doe there hath bin, as I [am told]
by some among them, and yet I see it is un[certain]
when or howe they will conclude: albeyt by al[l con-]
jecture, I thinke w
t
in these 3 dayes they wil[l make]
somewhat of it, But because it is in doubt and
e [time]
may seeme longe since I writte unto yo
r
L. hav[ing bin]
for these 10 dayes, put in hope from daye to d[aye,]
of some final resolution, I thought it needefull [the while]
to informe you what had passed, wherein I see [no]
disposition (howsoever they may happen to be secr[etly]
minded) to condescend to any portion of p
nt
rem[boursement.]
But onely to make knowen,
at this paym
t
is [demanded]
before
e day, and out of season for
at
e warre[s are]
not ended, and
e Contrey hath no meanes, w
ch
[will]
also be
e tenor, by
at which I can yet ghesse of th[eir letters]
and message, for
at I thinke they will agree upon
e [one or]
e other. It should seeme by a clause [in your]
L. l
re
at you understoode certaine wordes w[hich I]
had used in my l
re
s of
e 27 of Au
g
and 11 [of September]
of a newe and an other kinde of Treatie w[ith her]
as if
e States had a
purpose to renewe
e
Treatie
Ma
tie
, whereas I understood it, of a newe agr[eement]
altogether: w
t
other newe conditions, as to sign[ifie to]
yo
r
L: wherupon I writte it, I had put
e q
e
stion [in]
co
m
unic
ao
n to some two or three heere why they [made]
it nowe so hard to finde money for her Ma
tie
if [they]
meant to make paym
t
of these Annual rembour[sements]
w
t
entertayning so many English, as my ouvertur[e de-]
lyvered at my last coming home? To this
e pa[rties]
made answear with whome I dealt in
at mater,
fol.190r
That it was not possible to cause
e Provinces to
acknowledge
at
e terme of
e Contract is expired,
when
e wordes and
e text are so plaine against it,
and
at they would not be induced to make any re-
titution as for debt alreadie dewe, but by proposing
unto them some other forme of Treatie, They might have
bin intreated by good handling of their humors, to
cancell
e old, and so
suaded indirectly to have inclu-
ded in a newe, certaine yerly payments, for her Hig
es
contentation in regard of her former charges. Heereupon
it was
at I did insinuat, that as farre as I could
learne, if any thing were obtained, it must come by
e meanes of a newe accord. But of any resolution
either taken or intended to be taken about it, I am
utterly ignorant. For as occasions may be given, if
they chance to send their Deputies, they are lyke enough
in secret to conclude other maters, as their usuall
maner is, and also afterwardes in
England
to auto-
rise them to deale, as any motion to their lyking shall
happen to proceede from her Ma
tie
or themselves.
When
I presse them somewhat neere in privat conver-
sation, to tell me, how they can prevent
e subversion
of their State, if her Ma
tie
should protest and w
t
drawe
her assistance, their answear savoureth altogether
of a desperat moode. Loth, they say, they would be to con-
test w
t
her Hig
es
, and will shunne it, as they may, in
all duetifull sort,
at
e Enemie may not triumph, and
turne it to his benefitte: but if she force them unto it,
by her publicke protestations, they have but to muche
to alleage, both to justefie themselves in
e sight of
e world, and to notifie to all men, w
t
w
at
patience
ei
have boaren
e breaches of
e contract exceedingly greatly
to their prejudice. And if withall shee will proceede
to deprive them of
their
her
aide, they must, and will provide
to trust unto themselves, and to suche helpes as god shall
send, it having bin ever their destinie to deffend
their libertie and rightes with adversitie and trou-
bles. But if otherwise then well should befalle their
Estate, it would be seene but oversoone
at Englandes
staffe standes nexte
e doare. I calle to mynde
fol.190v
many tymes
at her Ma
tie
in her speeches of
[e affaires]
of these Contreys, hath seemed often so to buil[d upon]
e affections of
e people, as if
e Generallitie w[ere]
more addicted to content her, then this assemblie [of]
their Deputies; and
at the Inhabitants of
e To[wnes]
might be drawen by remonstrance to be refourm[e and]
disavowe
e dealings of their Delegates. T[his]
was so out of question at
e making of
e Co[ntract]
and so continued somw
at
after, untill they gre[we out]
of lyking w
t
some courses,
at were held by s[ome]
Ministers of her Ma
tie
, and reduced their E[state]
to some better forme of gouvernment. But []
these 6 or 7 yeares, I have found
e peop[le]
very willing to be guided by their Deputies, [who]
also very warie to knowe howe farre they may [pre-]
sume. For though somew
at
sometymes be d[one by]
their Deputies against their humors and [opinions]
yet it is
butt
very seldome in maters of moment [and]
I could never yet observe
at there was any [thing]
controlled or co
u
termanded by
e people,
at [they]
had once ordained: which is
e pacience, they [will]
use, for preservation of their union, wherof [I thought]
it not amisse to touche a worde unto your [L.]
if happelie some course of proposing maters [to the]
co
m
ons, should seeme expedient for her M[ajesty]
The losse of
e towne of
Cambray
doth m[inister]
muche mater of newe discourses in this Co[ntrey]
very many men disliking
at carelesse deali[ng of]
e King, and misdoubting least their succors [will]
proove but ill bestowed: in so much
at I pe[rceave,]
unles
at somew
at
w
t
speede be atchieved by [the]
King for
e advancem
t
of
eir cause, he sha[ll find]
them for heereafter a great deale streiter [laced]
in assisting him w
t
money. But yet th[is last]
Absolution doth keepe their heades busied ab[ove all]
other maters: as
at which they account w[will entice]
him ere be longe to some attonement w
t
e Spaniard
and drawe this Contrey shortly after into no[table]
inconvenience
s
. W
at
opinion
e Enemie con[ceaveth]
of a Peace yo
r
L. may conjecture by
e [letter]
fol.189r
heerew
t
of
e
Marquis of Havre
, to
e Count of Berghe[n]
which was lately intercepted, and sent us from
e
Campe. I have also seene an other to
e self same
effect, from a chieffe man of
Brusselles,
to a privat
person heere. It is geven out by
e Marquis,
and is confirmed by our co
m
on occurrences,
at
Comissioners appointed by
e Chamber of Spyres, to
come hither to mediate an Acord w
t
e Spaniard
are nowe in consultation at
Frankfort
or
Collen.
Many men heere suspect,
at for
e furtherance of
this Peace, the release of their
Shippes and
gooddes
is artificially dallied of till
e co
m
ing
oy
of
e Cardi-
nal and
e
P. of Orenge
(who are expected very
shortlie)
at they may be offerers of
at speciall grace
and favor, and
suade both
e owners and other by
their meanes, to listen so much
e sooner to their
desyred Pacification. I have enquired very
harde to knowe
e autor of
at Frenche discorse
w
ch
I sent to my
L. of Essex
, but no bodie heere can
tell it for certaine: albeyt it is fathered by
e most
upon
Lipsi[us],
who hath handled by report
at subject
in a l
re
, and
at doth savo
r
altogether his stile and
forme of writing. There is intelligence come from
Andwerp,
at
e Indian Fleete arryved at S
t
Lucar
in
Spaine
e 7 of Sep
t
w
t
10 Millions. I thinke
yo
r
L.hath heard
at
Haringuieres
e Governo
r
of
Breda,
by whome
Huy
was surprised in Fe
b
last, hath attempted
e lyke upon
e Towne of
Lier
,
a very strong place in
e Dukedome of
Brabant
,
about two Leagues from Andwerp, where he and
his troupe of 7 or 8 hundred, of which many
were disguised in boores apparell, and came in
earlie in a morning in an Oxe market daye, sea-
sing on a gate possessed p
nt
ly
e Towne, the
Munition howse
e Market place, and every
gate saving one, which they kept without
impeachement, from 5 in
e morning till 3 in
e
afternoone, and then for want of good order
e soldiers falling to
e spoile,
e Bourghers
tooke armes and other Soldiers to
e nomber of
fol.189v
200 came from Andwerp, Malines and [Heren]
tals which slewe, as we thinke 500 of ou[rs,]
and put
e rest to flight. And thus o
r
[happe]
is all this eyre to come home by weep[ing]
Crosse in all
e attemptes we take in hande[.]
In effect what with
at and
e Plottes,
at [are]
casting to enforce a Pacification, and
e co[urses]
held in
France,
w
t
those other considerati[ons,]
which I enlarged to yo
r
L.
e 17 of Aug[ust together]
w
t
e mater of my message unto them, [they are]
so muche amased, and so fearfull least [the]
people should beginne to take a head, an[d re-]
volt in some quarter, which they doubt [, may]
drawe after the bodie of their Confederaci[e, as]
I never sawe them for any thing, albeit I [have]
bin heere in divers greatte astonishement [so]
abjectly minded, as they are at this p
nt
.
And yet in my opinion there doth nothing [progno-]
sticat so great a danger towardes as
e g[rudges]
and discordes betweene Province and P[rovinces]
in contributing their portions, and
e envi[es and]
dislykes
at are secretly kindled, but s[mothe-]
red for
e tyme, among
e chiefest of [the contrey,]
which may occasion on
e suddaine a disu[nion]
of
e States, when so many other causes co[ncurre]
to helpe it forwardes. Nowe they see a[nd]
complaine of
e wante of a P. Orenge or [of some]
suiteable person, to compose these cou[vert]
quarels, to hold
e Provinces together in [good]
correspondence, to animat
e people in these [cases]
of desaster, and to propose in other accide[nts, the]
meetest meanes to be embraced for
e be[nefit]
of
e Contrey.
Count Maurice
is you[ng, and]
voyde of experience not deliting to meddle [with]
affaires of
e State, and in a maner among [the]
rest there is equalitie altogether, so as n[one]
will undertake to be autors of a project in a [bu-]
sinesse of importance least it should n[ot]
speede aright, unles it may be some one,
fol.191r
who by reason of his place as Advocat of
Holland
hath great opportunities to effect his dssignes
and is by Nature very pregnant to plotte and devise
so as having bin fortunate in
e issue of some
Counsailes, beyond all expectation, he hath ca-
ried away
e credit in contriving and mana-
ging most maters of
e State. Howbeyt his
coegnals mutter at it, and his betters so dis-
daine it, as if his fortune chance to foule him,
it will quicklie goe amisse with his credit and
countenance. And thus
e weight of this cause
is
e occasion of my lenght, and of many
pointes inserted, of which I thought it not
impertinent to make some litle mention, besee
ching you most humblie to make relation to
her Ma
tie
of what you thinke behoofull, and to
affourd my service
at reporte, as in yo
r
hono-
rable judgment you shall finde it doth deserve.
And so I take my humble leave Hag 19 Oct
o
95
.
